comments.text:
dammit, tin, not lead. apologies.

there are also heating elements on the assembly line. to make the glass 
cool down more evenly. effectively reducing surface tension which makes the 
glass much easier to cut. (this is also part of the myth, as it gives an 
illusion of glass material changing over time, it ofc does not)
comments.author: yunthi

comments.text:
+Neeboopsh
yeah that technique was used after the centrifugal, i think early 1900. not 
sure how far back. (dont quote me on the dates, im really bad at 
remembering them)

the one they pulled it thu rollers was i think around 1940 up until 70s or 
so.

its also part of the myth of flowing glass, the mouthblown had lots of 
flowing patterns to it, and airbubbles. since it was flowing before it 
cooled down, 
and ofc a bit newer glass it was the roller marks which give the glass 
relatively even but still sortof flowing looking pattern (it was always 
installed upright)
and new float is optically "perfect". 

the mouthblown glass might also be a bit thicker at the bottom , which was 
due to the uneven thickness of it. while inside the straightening kiln, the 
heavier part would remain straight while thinner parts would curve back a 
bit while it cools down, and one would install it the straight (read 
heavier / thicker end) down. nail it down and then use the runner to press 
the curved part against the frame. (which is the reason if fixing these 
windows, one must start from the top, it might spring on you and fall if 
starting from the bottom and sides like with float generally)

mouthblown glass is still used in some museum buildings etc, but its blown 
much thicker than they used to so it doesn´t have the curving issue 
anymore.
comments.author: yunthi

comments.text:
+yunthi Awesome. Yeah i forget which low temp metal it floats on (hence the 
name) i thought i made it clear that it did actually float but specific 
alloy or compound was unknown [due to drinking]  at the moment. i did not 
know that they would blow into squares and use that. that would be a fairly 
accurate flat.   hashtagYAYGLASS
comments.author: Neeboopsh

comments.text:
+Neeboopsh float is literally floating on a compound of mostly molten lead, 
(+ other stuff, simply to raise the boiling point of lead above glass 
melting point) that is heavier than the glass, so glass will float on top. 
this method makes it pretty much optically flawless.

unlike the previous methods where it was squeezed thu rollers

or the older mouthblown glass which is basically an elongated balloon where 
top and bottom are cut off and then the cylinder cut open. after which its 
put to a kiln where the glass cylinder is opened to a square.
comments.author: yunthi

comments.text:
If the question is "how is glass made?", as in glass which can be found in 
windows, etc. its an amorphous solid made some kind of silicate, like 
quartz. which is found in rocks and sand. basically its just heated to 
melting , removed of impurities by separation and then pouring into a blob 
of glass. with more heat you can reshape glass into anything you want in a 
mould or by blowing (how jars and other containers are made). float glass 
(stuff in a flat window) is poured molten onto  a flat suface with a liquid 
covering it and as it floats along its cooling and made quite flat. If i 
remember right, old methods of making flat(ish) glass was using a 
centrifuge which actually made the glass slightly thicker at the outer 
points, which is why you find old pieces of glass appear slightly wavy or 
that vary in thickness from one edge to the other. some glass is still made 
like that for specific purposes (focusing mirrors for large mirror 
telescopes)
comments.author: Neeboopsh

top_comment.text: So why do pointy pieces of metal spark in microwaves? :|﻿
top_comment.author: Niall Lyn-McKee

comments.text:
I think it's very similar to why you produce a shock when touching metal, 
or the way lightning works. Basically, the less surface area a conducting 
object has (or better yet, the smaller the radius), the smaller the amount 
of energy it can store before breaking down and produce a "spark". This is 
why a Van de Graaff (yes I had to look up how to spell that) electrostatic 
generator is a giant metal sphere whit no sharp edges. This optimizes the 
charge in can hold (or the amount of energy) without "sparking" (I believe 
the scientific term for the spark is 'corona'). Another fantastic example 
of this idea is a capacitor. These are battery like objects composed of two 
thin metal foil sheets rolled up with a sheet of a non conducting material 
in between them, and stuck in a small cylinder The size of the sheets and 
the efficiency of the non conducting material between them are directly 
related to the amount of energy these capacitors can hold. The best proof 
though is to look at the equations for voltage, energy fields, potential 
energy, potential energy of a field, and notice that all of them have 'r' 
in the denominator standing for 'radius'. This is my best guess; I'll admit 
I'm not positive.
comments.author: Donald Timpson

comments.text:
Because they are not organic and even worse a conducting material. It just 
collects the energy and releases it violently. That cannot happen with 
plastic since the waves cannot interact with that material.

The radiation warning would refer to the danger of being burnt if you 
manage to turn on the microwave without it being in its casing.  Radiation 
essentially refers to anything that radiates, like radiant heat, or in this 
case radiating microwaves.  If anything was radioactive,  there would be 
that radioactive symbol as part of the warning, and it wouldn't be a common 
household item if it was that threatening.

comments.text:
+zehmeester +DuHaMuT Thank you both. I started reading this, and was 
getting ready to write a fair sized paragraph:p One thing I might include 
is science also deals a lot with accurately modeling. For example, all 
physics students first use 9.81 m/s^2  or 10 m/s^2 for the force of 
gravity, independent of the objects mass, and ignoring air resistance. This 
very accurately models what we see here on the surface of the earth, and 
while Einsteins equations are the "most accurate" (I doubt a scientist 
would ever say true), Galileo's calculations are good enough.

comments.text:
All that's written by men is flawed to a certain extent. All the science is 
constantly evolving after new theories are developed and new evidence is 
collected. How do you think you are able read that on your computer or 
smart phone screen? The progress is all about challenging beliefs and 
building on the current ideas and theories. And actually you can be sure of 
what the scientists are saying! Even though Newton has been proven wrong, 
the gravity still works, and his formulas are still valid for the scale 
they were developed for! So don't be afraid that something might change or 
that we don't know everything... Be excited about it!
comments.author: DuHaMuT

comments.text:
There seems to be a severe lack of understanding of the scientific method 
in this discussion. 

+Goodliferacing (and +Danislav zagi) "Science" (pardon the quotes) learned 
a long time ago there really is no such thing as "truth" as you put it. 
However, science is in the business of finding provisional truths. That is 
to say when some explanation fits the observed data, it is considered true 
until it isn't, hence provisionally. I also hear hedged statements all the 
time along the lines of "This is only one study, but it appears that..." 
and so on. And like +InMaTeofDeath said, studies are not to be confused 
with theories.
comments.author: zehmeester

comments.text:

top_comment.author: mazdaplz

comments.text:
+mazdaplz

You may be a bit paranoid. But let me explain some of the things you may be 
feeling.

The microwave has a fan, so you might actually be experiencing wind. Also 
the plastic front can generate static electricity. It either shocks you or 
it doesn't. Static is not bad for health persay. As I explained above, the 
wavelength of microwaves (a few inches)  is too big to pass through the 
small little holes. So whatever you are feeling, it's not microwaves. It 
can be a number of other things. Light, X-Ray, Gamma rays. Lucky for you, 
the generator and wave guides used in a microwave is unable to generate 
such frequencies.

While you may stay away from wifi and cellphones, you are still being 
bombarded by radio waves, cosmic radiation, satellite radiation and natural 
background radiation from things like bananas and concrete. So no escape 
for you unfortunately. You are bathed in radiation like the rest of us.

As a species, we understand the principles and manipulation of EM radiation 
better then we understand the flu. So don't fret, you'll survive.


If it really bothers you, pick up a second hand oscilloscope and probe 
around the house for sources of EMF.
comments.author: Balee Tong

i always felt it with either of my 20 models of microwave i've had over the 
years, it's nice to know the faraday cage is there but if you just put your

so don't tell me NONE of the microwaves go through,

and by the way to the commenters above i do not use a celphone, for a

well since they are mildly toxic

and no i have wifi in my house but on this floor i am connected through a 
wire.

captions.text:
How do microwaves cook your food? If you stand
in front of a microwave are you going to get
cancer? Are they killing you?!

Howdy cookers, thanks for watching DNews,
I'm Trace. This morning, I was talking to

our intern Tori // hello! // about how I microwaved
coffee from yesterday. Yeah, I know, it's

gross. But it's SO EASY! Microwaves are magic
food boxes. They heat food in less time with

less energy than traditional methods -- but
HOW they make that thing hotter is a mystery
to many of it's users...

The microwave has roots in radar research
during World War II. Scientist Percy Spencer

accidentally melted a candybar in his pocket
and after some more experimentation, he patented[a]

the first microwave heating device! Microwaves
are basically metal boxes containing a magnetron

gun. The magnetron uses electricity to excite
electrons and get them to vibrate and release

waves of non-ionized electromagnetic energy.
This radiation is at a frequency that's between

radio waves and infrared light -- usually
around 2.45 gigahertz. This microwave "radiation"

is no different from the radiation created
by a radio station or a wifi-network.

The literal microwaves are made of alternating
current, and magnetic fields. Because it's

Alternating it means they're switching from
clockwise to counterclockwise back and forth.

These electromagnetic waves shoot from the
magnetron into the oven passing through paper,

plastic, and glass to hit the water, fat and
sugar molecules in your cup of coffee or frozen
burrito.

Scientists aren't EXACTLY sure what happens
at this point. Either the waves cause the

H2O molecules to agitate and generate heat,
OR the fats, sugars and water absorb the energy

and release heat. Either way, when the magnetron
energy hits, heat is created, and a minute

or so later, yesterday's coffee is as good
as… well yesterday's coffee. Only hotter.

Because it's just heating water, fat and sugar
-- if it's not evenly distributed throughout

the burrito, it won't heat well! Cold patch,
yuck... Also, setting it too hot too fast

will only mess up the process because the
heat has to travel into the food by conduction,

that is, one molecule spreads heat to the
next and then the next. What a pain in the
butt.

My mom used to tell me, "If you want children
someday don't stand too close to the microwave!"

Which isn't really true. This microwave radiation
isn't nearly as strong an an x-ray, or as

common as wifi, cell phone, televisions or
other electromagnetic waves flying around.

Studies have found low-level microwave exposure
shouldn't cause the corruption of DNA that

results in cancer. And looking into the microwave
is fine, the windows are shielded so microwaves

are reflecting onto the food, not into your
sensitive little eyeballs.

Metal in the microwave, isn't inherently bad,
either. After all, the walls are made of it

because it reflects the waves all around,
heating as much of the food as possible. However,

throwing in something POINTY, like aluminum
foil, can cause sparks, and breakdown of air

molecules into more dangerous fumes. The sleeves
that come with some pastries are also for

reflection, because as the outside of the
food heats up, that heat energy is reflected

BACK at the crust, crisping it up. It's cooking
itself!

Whether microwaving is damaging the food is
still being debated by science, but for the

most part ANY cooking damages the nutrient
content of the "raw" food, but cooking it

also kills bacteria which makes food safer.
Yes, a few older studies found breast milk,

heated in a microwave, lost some of it's vitamin
B12 potency. But many other studies have found

no such evidence. And MANY studies done on
microwaves have determined there's little

or no difference between microwaving and conventional
cooking. Ultimately, the most dangerous things

microwaves produce are food burns from overheating
the item. And that's just your fault. The

FDA says microwaving food is just as safe
and nutritious as any other method of cooking.

But what do you think? Are you nervous about
them? Do you microwave your food?

Speak your mind down in the comments and be
sure you subscribe for more DNews. Microwaves

are also produced in space, and on Wednesday,
August 27 we're doing our next monthly SpaceOut

with NASA/JPL! This month we're talking about
Europa, the possibility of life and future

missions to Jupiter's intriguing moon! RSVP
with the link here or in the description and

post a question so we can ask the experts!
Thanks for watching DNews.
